'''Fíriel''' was the daughter of [[Orontor]] of [[Númenor]] according to the early version of the [[legendarium]] in ''[[The Lost Road]]''.

== History ==
She was a fair [[Númenóreans|Númenórean]] maiden of the household of [[Elendil]]. While Elendil and his son [[Herendil]] were approaching their house, they heard Fíriel sing a [[Fíriel's song|sad song]] from a high window in the [[Quenya|Eressëan]] tongue that Elendil and [[Herendil]] heard the first two lines of, beginning with "''Ilu Ilúvatar en káre''" ("The Father made the World")<ref name=P1>{{LR|P1III2}}, pp. 62-3</ref><ref>{{VT|45a}}, p. 12</ref> and going until her voice fell into the question "''O Ilúvatar, give me in that day beyond the end, when my Sun faileth?''" Then Elendil said "''E man antaváro? What will he give indeed?''" Herendil complained, saying that she should not be singing such things, as people in Númenor were now singing that [[Melko]] would come back and give them the Sun forever, but his father despised those words.<ref name=Firiel>{{LR|P1III2}}{{rp|62–63}}</ref>

== Etymology ==
''Fíriel'' is only glossed in ''[[The Etymologies]]'' as a [[Noldorin]] name of [[Lúthien]], meaning "Mortal Maiden", from ''feir'' ("mortal"), and ''[[-iel]]'' ("daughter").<ref>{{LR|Etymologies}}, entry "PHIR-"</ref>

== Other versions of the legendarium ==
While Tolkien eventually discarded the character of Fíriel, the name would later be used for [[Fíriel (disambiguation)|other characters]] within the [[legendarium]].
